t: Job 11
Zophar Speaks: You Deserve Worse
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Should*pn a multitude of words go unanswered, and*ld a man full of talk be judged right?
Should*ln your babble silence men, and*ld when you mock, shall no one shame you?
For*ln you say, ‘My doctrine is pure, and*ld I am clean in God’s eyes.’
But*ln oh, that God would speak and*ld open his lips to you,
and*ln that he would tell you the secrets of wisdom! For*ld he is manifold in understanding. Know*ln then that God exacts of you less than your guilt deserves.
“Can*pn you find out the deep things of God? Can*ld you find out the limit of the Almighty?
It*ln is higher than heaven— what can you do? Deeper*ld than Sheol— what can you know?
Its*ln measure is longer than the earth and*ld broader than the sea.
If*ln he passes through and imprisons and*ld summons the court, who can turn him back?
For*ln he knows worthless men; when*ld he sees iniquity, will he not consider it?
But*ln a stupid man will get understanding when*ld a wild donkey’s colt is born a man!
“If*pn you prepare your heart, you*ld will stretch out your hands toward him.
If*ln iniquity is in your hand, put it far away, and*ld let not injustice dwell in your tents.
Surely*ln then you will lift up your face without blemish; you*ld will be secure and will not fear.
You*ln will forget your misery; you*ld will remember it as waters that have passed away.
And*ln your life will be brighter than the noonday; its*ld darkness will be like the morning.
And*ln you will feel secure, because there is hope; you*ld will look around and take your rest in security.
You*ln will lie down, and none will make you afraid; many*ld will court your favor.
But*ln the eyes of the wicked will fail; all*ld way of escape will be lost to them, and*ld their hope is to breathe their last.”
